    6-Halopyridylmethylidene Penicillin-Based Sulfones Efficiently Inactivate the Natural Resistance of Pseudomonas aeruginosa to β-Lactam Antibiotics

    • Juan C. Vázquez-Ucha

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a major cause of nosocomial infections, is considered a paradigm of antimicrobial resistance, largely due to hyperproduction of chromosomal cephalosporinase AmpC. Here, we explore the ability of 6-pyridylmethylidene penicillin-based sulfones 1–3 to inactivate the AmpC β-lactamase and thus rescue the activity of the antipseudomonal ceftazidime. These compounds increased the susceptibility to ceftazidime in a collection of clinical isolates and PAO1 mutant strains with different ampC expression levels and also improved the inhibition kinetics relative to avibactam, displaying a slow deacylation rate and involving the formation of an indolizine adduct. Bromide 2 was the inhibitor with the lowest KI (15.6 nM) and the highest inhibitory efficiency (kinact/KI). Computational studies using diverse AmpC enzymes revealed that the aromatic moiety in 1–3 targets a tunnel-like site adjacent to the catalytic serine and induces the folding of the H10 helix, indicating the potential value of this not-always-evident pocket in drug design.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The treatment of infections caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is one of the top three critical priority pathogens identified by the World Health Organization, is probably one of the major clinical problems in the field of infectious diseases at present. This is not only due to an intrinsically high resistance but also due to the natural propensity of the bacterium to develop multidrug resistance via selection of mutations in chromosomal genes or via the horizontal acquisition of broad spectrum resistance mechanisms.(1) The prevalence of multidrug-resistant (MDR) and extensively drug-resistant P. aeruginosa strains has increased dramatically in the last few years, highlighting the urgent need for new antipseudomonal drugs.(2−6)
    In Gram-negative bacteria, the most important mechanism of resistance to β-lactam antibiotics, which represent about 70% of all antibacterial drugs in clinical use,(7) is the enzymatic hydrolysis of the β-lactam ring catalyzed by β-lactamases. This machinery is particularly challenging in P. aeruginosa because, in addition to the plasmid-mediated resistance observed in other bacteria, this bacterium possesses a chromosomal class C β-lactamase (AmpC, encoded by ampC gene) known as PDC (for Pseudomonas-derived cephalosporinase), which can be induced in most clinical isolates by some of the β-lactam antibiotics themselves.(8) This gives P. aeruginosa the ability to regulate the level of resistance on demand via production of the AmpC enzyme, thus making the bacterium intrinsically resistant to β-lactam antibiotics, including aminopenicillins and cephalosporins. Thus, when the ampC gene is derepressed and is constitutively producing high levels of the enzyme, it becomes the major cause of resistance to many antipseudomonal β-lactam therapies.(9,10) Metallo-β-lactamase enzymes such as VIM and IMP are also involved in an important resistance mechanism in P. aeruginosa.(11) Other secondary and also relevant β-lactam resistance mechanisms include (i) loss of the outer membrane protein, OprD, which is involved in carbapenem resistance,(12) and (ii) overproduction of efflux pumps.(13) The combination of these chromosomal resistance mechanisms frequently leads to the emergence of clinical isolates that are resistant to virtually all β-lactam antibiotics.
    Ceftazidime/avibactam and ceftolozane/tazobactam are new combination therapies of β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitors with enhanced stability against AmpC-mediated hydrolysis and efflux mechanisms, which have recently been introduced into the clinical setting to alleviate the urgent clinical need for novel antipseudomonal β-lactam antibiotics.(14) Nevertheless, use of these therapies is somewhat cautiously restricted, and dosing is optimized in order to prevent selection of in vivo resistance.(2,15) In addition, the increasing catalogue of reports documenting the emergence of AmpC-mediated resistance during therapy is of serious concern.(16−18) A few other alternatives are being developed and are currently at different phases of clinical trials: (i) new DBO (1,6-diazabicyclo[3.2.1]octane) inhibitors, imipenem/relebactam, and cefepime/zidebactam;(19−22) (ii) cyclic boronate inhibitors such as meropenem/vaborbactam(23) and cefepime/taniborbactam;(24,25) and (iii) a new tazobactam analogue, cefepime/enmetazobactam (Figure 1).(26)
    In recent years, our research group has been exploring the therapeutic potential of 6-arylmethylidene penicillin-based sulfones as new β-lactamase inhibitors that could recover antibiotic efficacy (Figure 2A).(27) This research has demonstrated the efficacy of the 2-pyridylmethylidene derivative 1 (LN-1-255) against the relevant carbapenemase OXA-48(28) and against all of the carbapenem-hydrolyzing class D β-lactamases of the pathogen Acinetobacter baumannii,(29) which also displayed good efficacy in preclinical models of murine pneumonia.(30) The key structural features responsible for the effectiveness of compound 1 relative to other penicillin-based sulfones (sulbactam, tazobactam) are (i) the catechol moiety (siderophore), which improves internalization through bacterial iron uptake pathways, and (ii) the 2-pyridylmethylene group, which can generate an indolizine adduct II that is resistant to hydrolysis. The latter compound would be generated by nucleophilic attack of the pyridine nitrogen on the conjugated imine adduct I that would result from opening the dioxothiazolidine ring (Figure 2B). The available crystal structures of OXA-24/40 from A. baumannii covalently modified by 2-pyridylmethylidene penicillin-based sulfone inhibitors (PDB IDs 3MBZ, 3FYZ, 3FZC and 3FV7) suggest that the indolizine moiety would increase the hydrophobicity of the active site, thus hindering the approach of the water molecule for the final hydrolysis and turnover.(31) A similar effect would be expected for OXA-48, which also has a large hydrophobic region close to the active site.
    We have recently explored the effect on the inhibitory efficacy of 1 of changes in the electron density of its pyridine ring by the incorporation of diverse substituents, compounds 1–5, and by using larger pyridine-based heterocycles, compounds 6–7 (Figure 2A).(32) The best results were obtained by reducing the electron density of the ring in 1 by the introduction of a bromide (para) or a fluoride (meta) substituent, compounds 2 and 3, respectively. These derivatives maintained or improved the activity of the parent compound 1 against carbapenem-hydrolyzing class D β-lactamases (OXA-23, OXA-24/40, and OXA-48). Docking studies with the OXA-24/40 enzyme suggested that these electron-deficient aromatic rings enhance CH−π interactions with the apolar residues of the tunnel-like entrance surrounding these compounds. Compounds 2 and 3 also restored the antibiotic efficacy in Escherichia coli strain-carrying class A (TEM-1 and CTX-M-2) and class C (CMY-2 and DHA-1) β-lactamases. These promising results, together with the alarming worldwide reduction in the efficacy of antibacterial drugs against the priority pathogen P. aeruginosa, encouraged us to explore the capacity of these derivatives to rescue the activity of antipseudomonal cephalosporin ceftazidime. As discussed below, preliminary susceptibility studies with the strain P. aeruginosa PAO1 ΔampD (hyperexpresing AmpC) and compounds 1–7 revealed the higher capacity of compounds 1–3 than of the other compounds to restore antibiotic efficacy, which were therefore selected for detailed exploration of their therapeutic potential for MDR P. aeruginosa. We report here microbiological studies on the susceptibility of compounds 1–3 in the presence of the antimicrobial ceftazidime with a complete collection of P. aeruginosa PAO1 isogenic mutant strains and clinical isolates with different levels of ampC expression. The results of kinetic studies of compounds 1–3 against the PDC-1 enzyme (AmpC wild-type from PAO1 strain and widely spread in P. aeruginosa), in combination with docking and molecular dynamics (MD) simulation studies on the enzyme complexes and their corresponding acyl-enzyme adducts, allowed us to demonstrate the key structural features of the efficacy of the compounds. Moreover, simulation studies with other AmpC enzymes (BER, CMY-10) also show that the aromatic moiety of the ligands induces folding of the H10 helix and the formation of a tunnel-like site, which is not always evident and in which the indolizine adduct would be deeply buried.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Susceptibility Studies

    The ability of compounds 1–7 to increase the antipseudomonal activity of ceftazidime against the mutant P. aeruginosa PAO1 ΔampD, derived from the parental reference strain PAO1, was first measured. Other than AmpC (PDC-1), this strain does not possess other relevant mechanisms of resistance to β-lactam antibiotics and exhibits low levels of resistance. The minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) of ceftazidime were determined, in the absence and presence of compounds 1–7 at a fixed concentration of 16 mg/L, and the results were compared with avibactam as a reference β-lactamase inhibitor. The preliminary results showed that the antibiotic activity of ceftazidime can be fully restored when it is combined with compounds 1–3 and 6, while only 50% or less activity is achieved with derivatives 4–5 and 7 (Table S1). These results, together with the twofold reduction in the capacity of compound 6 to rescue the imipenem activity against bacterial strains harboring carbapenem-hydrolyzing class D β–lactamases (OXA-23, OXA-24/40, and OXA-48) (Tables S2 and S3),(32) led us to select compounds 1–3 for further studies with MDR strains of P. aeruginosa with different capacities to produce the AmpC enzyme. To this end, isogenic mutants of P. aeruginosa PAO1 strain with different ampC expression levels (encoding the PDC β-lactamase) were used to determine the microbiological activity of the compounds 1–3 in a genetic background lacking other β-lactam resistance mechanisms. This is a well-characterized collection of P. aeruginosa strains expressing multiple combinations of genes implicated in ampC regulation and displaying different levels of AmpC hyperproduction, such as mutations of nonessential penicillin-binding proteins (PBP3, PBP4, and PBP7) and AmpC regulators (AmpD, AmpDh2, and AmpDh3). In addition, we also evaluated the activity of these inhibitors in a collection of MDR P. aeruginosa clinical isolates displaying different levels of ampC expression. The isolates were obtained from respiratory tract samples from patients with ventilator-associated pneumonia enrolled in the Magic Bullet clinical trial in different countries in Europe. The bacterial strains used are listed in Table 1.
    Table 1. Laboratory Strains and Clinical Isolates Used in this Study
    bacterial straindescriptionreference
    PAO1completely sequenced reference strain.laboratory collection
    PAOΔCPAO1 ampC knockout mutant(18)
    PAOΔC + pUCP-(PDC-1)PAO1 ampC knockout mutant (PAOΔC) complemented with PDC-1(51)
    PAOΔC + pUCP-(PDC-5)PAO1 ampC knockout mutant (PAOΔC) complemented with PDC-5 (which presents a similar hydrolysis profile than PDC-1)(16)
    PAO ΔampDPAO1 AmpD mutant(52)
    PAO ΔdacBPAO1 PBP4 mutant(51)
    PAO ΔdacBΔdacCPAO1 PBP4-PBP5 mutant(53)
    PAO ΔDΔDh2ΔDh3PAO1 AmpD-AmpDh2-AmpDh3 mutant(52)
    PAO ΔdacBΔdacCΔpbpGPAO1 PBP4-PBP5-PBP7 mutant(53)
    PAO ΔdacBΔampDPAO1 PBP4 AmpD mutant(80)
    PAHUAC-27 (ST-22)clinical isolatethis study
    PAHUAC-14 (ST-966)clinical isolatethis study
    13/09-018 (ST-175)clinical isolate(54)
    17/14-017 (ST-235)clinical isolate(54)
    23/14-053 (ST-309)clinical isolate(54)
    53/22-113 (ST-244)clinical isolate(54)
    36/14-210 (ST-235)clinical isolate(54)
    6/04-224 (ST-175)clinical isolate(54)
    As previously observed, ampC gene expression was correlated with ceftazidime resistance in the strains used.(33) As the level of expression of the ampC gene in the reference strain PAO1 is low, high susceptibility to ceftazidime [MIC of 1 mg/L] was observed. Remarkably, inactivation of the ampC gene and the resulting loss of AmpC production in the PAOΔC mutant did not imply a further decrease in the ceftazidime MICs. As expected, PAOΔC mutants complemented with PDC-1 or PDC-5 using the plasmid pUCP24 displayed high ampC expression levels. Furthermore, ampC expression was induced in single mutants of PBPs and ampD regulatory genes and increased accumulatively in double and triple mutants. As a result, a significant increase in the ceftazidime MIC (16–32 mg/L) was observed with all AmpC-overproducing PAO1 mutants (Table 2). Regarding clinical strains, a MIC of 8 mg/L was obtained with two isolates in which expression of the blaPDC-1 gene was lowest, and MICs of 16–128 mg/L were obtained with clinical strains in which expression of the ampC gene was at least 10-fold higher than that of the PAO1 strain. As these are clinical strains, they are likely to have other underlying mechanisms of resistance to β-lactam antibiotics in addition to chromosomal ampC cephalosporinase (Table 3).
    Table 2. Ceftazidime MICs Determined in the Presence of β-lactamase Inhibitors and blaampC RNA Expression Levels for PAO1 and Isogenic Mutants Expressing Multiple Combinations of ampC Regulatory Genes
      inhibitor at 4 mg/Linhibitor at 16 mg/L 
    strainCAZCAZ + AVICAZ + 1CAZ + 2CAZ + 3CAZ + AVICAZ + 1CAZ + 2CAZ + 3ampC RNA expressiona
    PAO11111111111
    PAOΔC1111111110
    PAOΔC + pUCP-(PDC-1)16111111111933.4 ± 264.1
    PAOΔC + pUCP-(PDC-5)16222212124084.8 ± 478.1
    PAO ΔampD1612180.511151.4 ± 4.2
    PAO ΔdacB1611110.50.50.50.536 ± 0.1
    PAO ΔDΔDh2ΔDh332241810.5111030.2 ± 172.5
    PAO ΔdacBΔpbpGΔdacC1611110.50.50.50.51109.9 ± 132.2
    PAO ΔdacBΔampD32484811121021.4 ± 140.7
    PAO ΔdacBΔdacC1611120.50.50.50.5472.3 ± 36.7
    a

    Relative ampC expression (with respect to PAO1). Mean values ± standard deviations for three independent experiments are shown.

    Table 3. Ceftazidime MICs Determined in the Presence of β-lactamase Inhibitors and blaampC RNA Expression Levels for Clinical Strains of P. aeruginosa
      inhibitor at 4 mg/Linhibitor at 16 mg/L 
    StrainCAZCAZ + AVICAZ + 1CAZ + 2CAZ + 3CAZ + AVICAZ + 1CAZ + 2CAZ + 3ampC RNA expressiona
    PAHUAC-27 (ST-22)3212141112326.4 ± 25.1
    PAHUAC-14 (ST-966)64416482222586.3 ± 45.8
    13/09-018 (ST-175)8222222222.4 ± 0.3
    17/14-017 (ST-235)164224422232.8 ± 1.7
    23/14-053 (ST-309)8122211226.4 ± 0.1
    53/22-113 (ST-244)64484844441415.3 ± 302.3
    36/14-210 (ST-235)1288161616488818.6 ± 0.6
    6/04-224 (ST-175)328888888810.1 ± 0.9
    a

    Relative ampC expression (with respect to PAO1). Mean values ± standard deviation for three independent experiments are shown.

    The results of comparative MIC assays for ceftazidime in combination with the different inhibitors showed that all inhibitors were able to increase the susceptibility to ceftazidime in strains with low, medium, or high expression of the ampC gene (Tables 2 and 3). Avibactam and inhibitors 1–3, at a concentration of 4 mg/L, were able to significantly increase susceptibility of the collection of PAO1-derived mutants to ceftazidime, with 8–16, 4–16, 8–32, and 2–16-fold increases, respectively; when tested at 16 mg/L, the susceptibility increased 16–32-fold in the presence of avibactam and compound 2, it increased 8–32-fold in the presence of compounds 1 and 3. When inhibitors were used at 16 mg/L, the ceftazidime MICs decreased to the baseline levels shown by the PAO1 and PAOΔC strains (lacking the ampC gene), which is an important indication of the total inhibition of the AmpC enzyme, regardless of the level of ampC expression. Remarkably, the PDC-5 β-lactamase of the mutant PAOΔC + pUCP-(PDC-5),(16) which displayed the highest ampC expression of the whole collection, was also inactivated by compounds 1–3 and avibactam in a similar way as in the PDC-1 in the PAOΔC + pUCP-(PDC-1) isogenic mutant. Regarding the MDR clinical strains, use of the inhibitors at 4 mg/L also increased the susceptibility to ceftazidime 4–32, 4–16, 4–32, and 4–8-fold when used in combination with avibactam and compounds 1–3, respectively. Finally, use of the inhibitors at 16 mg/L increased the susceptibility to the cephalosporin 4–32-fold with all the inhibitors tested.
    Following the EUCAST criteria, all strains used, that is, both PAO1 mutants and clinical isolates, were resistant to ceftazidime (breakpoint susceptibility of MIC ≤ 8 mg/L), except clinical isolates 13/09-018 and 23/14-053, for which the ceftazidime MIC was 8 mg/L. For all strains used in this study, the ceftazidime MICs were within the susceptibility range when tested in the presence of the inhibitors 1–3 and avibactam (16 mg/L). In summary, the penicillin-based sulfones 1–3 showed an inactivation efficacy in P. aeruginosa very similar to that of avibactam, which along with relebactam, is possibly the best class C β-lactamases inhibitor currently available.(34)

    Kinetics and Inhibition Studies

    Kinetic analysis of the inhibition of PDC-1 β-lactamase by compounds 1–3 is shown in Table 4. Nitrocefin was used as the reported substrate (Km = 34 μM) at a concentration of 120 μM to ensure a saturated concentration in the kinetic assays. Of the three inhibitors, bromide 2 displayed the highest inhibition efficiency kinact/KI (20.9 × 105 M–1 s–1), which was 3.3- and 4.2-fold higher than the values yielded by inhibitors 1 and 3, respectively. Compound 1 showed the best inactivation rate (kinact); however, the greatest differences were observed in the KI parameter, with compound 1 displaying the lowest affinity, with the highest KI value (74.8 nM), and the KI of compounds 2 and 3 being 4.8- and 2.7-fold lower, respectively. Similar inactivation efficiencies were indicated by the acylation rate (k2/K). Again, bromide 2 proved to be the best inhibitor of the series and displayed the highest values of k2/K (6.2 × 105 M–1 s–1). For avibactam, the k2/K value was 1366 M–1 s–1, which is consistent with the results obtained by other researchers.(35) Interestingly, the acylation rates of compounds 1, 2, and 3 were significantly higher than those of avibactam (110-, 454-, and 50-fold, respectively).
    Table 4. PDC-1 Inhibition Kinetics
    inhibitorIC50 (nM)Ki app (nM)k2/K (M–1 s–1)KI (nM)kinact (s–1)kinact/KI (M–1 s–1)tnkoff (min–1)t1/2 (min)
    Avibactama51.0 ± 3.1990 ± 751366 ± 430   182.6 × 10–2 ± 0.6 × 10–228 ± 7
    16.1 ± 1.953 ± 141.5 × 105 ± 0.5 × 10574.8 ± 18.90.046 ± 0.0066.3 × 105 ± 1.4 × 10519 × 10–3 ± 2 × 10–382 ± 19
    20.9 ± 0.0314 ± 46.2 × 105 ± 0.9 × 10515.6 ± 3.10.032 ± 0.00220.9 × 105 ± 3.1 × 10517 × 10–3 ± 2 × 10–3105 ± 29
    36.3 ± 1.0110 ± 186.8 × 104 ± 1.6 × 10428.2 ± 4.90.013 ± 0.0045.0 × 105 ± 1.2 × 10519 × 10–3 ± 2 × 10–378 ± 18
    Sulbactam4369.6 ± 791.3        
    Tazobactam844.4 ± 38.9        
    Clavulanic acid>200,000        
    a

    In the kobs determination for avibactam, saturating plots were not obtained and therefore it was not possible to obtain parameters KI, kinact, and kinact/KI.

    Similarly, the IC50 value of bromide 2 against PDC-1 (0.9 nM) was 6.8- and 7.0-fold lower than those of compounds 1 (6.1 nM) and 3 (6.3 nM) and, importantly, 57-fold lower than that of avibactam (51.0 nM). For purposes of comparison, we have included in the table the IC50 value of the commercially available β-lactamase inhibitors sulbactam, tazobactam, and clavulanic acid against the β-lactamase PDC-1 (4369, 844, and >200,000 nM, respectively). In these inhibitors, which display high affinity for class A β-lactamases, the IC50 value was much higher than in the 2-pyridylmethylidene penicillin-based sulfones 1–3.(36)
    In pre-steady-state conditions, compounds 1 and 2 showed the highest affinities for PDC-1, leading to Ki app values of 53 nM and 14 nM, respectively. By contrast, avibactam displayed the lowest affinity (990 nM), which was 71-fold lower than that of bromide 2. Moreover, the turnover number (tn), that is, the number of molecules of the inhibitor required to inactivate one molecule of the enzyme, was also measured. All the penicillin-based sulfones tested yielded a tn value of 1 with PDC-1. By contrast, the comparator avibactam displayed a tn of 18 with the β-lactamase.
    In order to analyze whether compounds 1–3 are reversible or irreversible inhibitors, the deacylation off-rate (koff) was determined by using the “jump-dilution” method, and the results were compared with those obtained with avibactam (Table 4). Like avibactam, the inhibition is reversible, but the koff values of the test compounds were much lower. Thus, while avibactam displayed a koff of 2.6 × 10–2 ± 0.6 × 10–2 min–1, which is equivalent to a residence time half-life (t1/2) of 28 ± 7 min, compounds 1, 2, and 3 showed koff values of 9 × 10–3 ± 2 × 10–3, 7 × 10–3 ± 2 × 10–3, and 9 × 10–3 ± 2 × 10–3 min–1, respectively, with t1/2 values of 82 ± 19, 105 ± 29, and 78 ± 18 min, respectively. These data suggest a slow deacylation process for compounds 1–3, indicating that the enzyme would remain inactivated for a longer time, with compound 2 being the best inhibitor.
    Comparison of compounds 1–3 revealed that bromide 2 exhibited a significantly higher inhibition efficacy (kinact/KI, p < 0.01) than compounds 1 and 3, mainly due to a higher affinity for chromosomal class C β-lactamase PDC-1 (reflected in lower IC50 or KI values), also displaying higher acylation rates (k2/K, p < 0.005).
    Moreover, in order to explore whether compounds 1–3 would also be capable of deactivating metallo-β-lactamases, for which effective therapies in clinical practice are currently not available, their inhibitory activity against the widespread metallo-β-lactamase VIM-1 was evaluated. Compounds 2 and 3 exhibited moderate activity against this enzyme, with Ki app values of 143 ± 45 and 192 ± 52 μM, respectively. Like avibactam, the inhibitory capacity of compound 1 against VIM-1 was lower, in both cases with Ki app values > 500 μM. Considering that compounds 2 and 3 in combination with ceftazidime, ampicillin, and imipenem also proved effective for restoring antibiotic efficacy in strains carrying class C (CMY-2 and DHA-1), class A (TEM-1 and CTX-M-2), and class D (OXA-23, OXA-24/40, and OXA-48) β-lactamases, respectively, the broad spectrum of activity of these halides appears to be relevant (Tables S2 and S3).(32)

    Mass Spectrometry Studies

    The covalent modification mechanism, whereby compounds 1–3 inhibit the PDC-1 enzyme, was studied by mass spectrometry [matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI)]. Inhibitors 1–3 were incubated with the enzyme at a 1:100 enzyme/ligand ratio in phosphate-buffered saline at pH 7.4 at 25 °C for 30 min and then analyzed by MALDI. The mass spectra of samples of the enzyme inactivated by compounds 1–3 consisted of a peak for the covalently modified enzyme, corresponding to an additional mass of 487, 565, and 503, respectively (Figure 3). These values are consistent with the theoretical mass increase values for the corresponding indolizine adducts (487, 566, and 506, respectively).

    Binding Mode—MD Simulation Studies

    To understand the molecular basis of the activity of the inhibitors 1–3 against the PDC-1 enzyme, MD simulation studies were carried out. These types of computational studies, in which both the ligand and the enzyme are considered flexible, are important complementary tools for drug discovery, enabling some insights to be gained into the atomic detail of the following: (i) the intrinsic shape-changing motions of the enzymes and the identification of less evident pockets; (ii) transitory enzyme/ligand complex species, such as the Michaelis complex that triggers the acylation process; (iii) the induced-fit capacity of the enzyme modulated by the ligand (“the conformation state”); and (iv) the binding mode of diverse ligands with related enzyme targets, even those for which no crystal structures are available (homology model) or for which the topology of the already solved ligands is quite different from that of the compounds under evaluation. For this type of study, it is important to know the spatial arrangement and protonation state of the key residues for catalysis, as both elements will control the binding of the ligand within the pocket. This proved to be an essential point here because, as discussed below, the identified differences between the reported ligands are largely due to their distinct interaction with the catalytic residue Tyr150. In this regard, AmpC enzymes have a Lys–Tyr–Lys triad (Lys67–Tyr150–Lys315) in the active site. The role of Lys67 and Tyr150 in the enzyme-catalyzed reaction has been widely discussed. It has been suggested that the phenolate form of Tyr150, which proved to have an abnormally low pKa (<9) at neutral pH, is responsible for (among other roles) activation of the catalytic serine in the acyl-enzyme adduct formation and that it is stabilized by the positively charged residues Lys67 and Lys315.(37,38) However, subsequent biochemical and mutagenesis studies revealed that Tyr150 is neutral during catalysis.(39) Both possibilities, that is, both neutral and ionic forms, were explored by studying the dynamic behavior of PDC-1 in the unbound form by using the protein coordinates in the crystal structure of AmpC from P. aeruginosa PAO1 (PDC-1, PDB ID 4GZB, 1.79 Å)(40) (Figure 4). The results showed that the appropriate arrangement of acyl-enzyme adduct formation with Ser64 (i.e., with the oxygen lone pair pointing toward the β-lactam carbonyl group) would only be achieved when Tyr150 and Lys67 are in their neutral forms and that this arrangement would be mainly controlled by Lys67 (see Figures S1 and S2 for further details). These protonation states were used in all subsequent studies.
    The binding modes of compounds 1–3 in the active site of PDC-1 were first studied by molecular docking, with GOLD software (version 5.8.1) and PDB ID 4GZB.(41) The highest scoring solutions were then subjected to 200 ns of dynamic simulation to produce reliable models of the PDC-1/1–3 enzyme binary complexes. These poses of the inhibitors placed the pyridine moiety (R1 side chain) in the vicinity of the H10 helix and the catechol group (R2 side chain) nearly adjacent to the Ω-loop. However, because β-lactam antibiotics, such as ceftazidime and ceftolozane, bind to class C β-lactamases by locating the side chain that supports the siderophore group (R1 side chain) in the vicinity of the Ω-loop and the chain that has the leaving group (R2 side chain) near the H10 helix region, scoring solutions showing a similar arrangement were also analyzed by MD simulation studies (Figure S3). These studies clearly showed that (i) under the latter orientation, the ligands rapidly moved away from the catalytic serine from the beginning of the simulation; (ii) the ligands proved to be poorly anchored to the active site because a wide variety of arrangements were identified; and in addition, (iii) the conformations of the ligands, in particular, the β-lactam carbonyl group, were not appropriate for nucleophilic attack and the formation of the acyl-enzyme adduct. On the contrary, the simulation studies were carried out with opposite disposition of the ligands, that is, with their siderophore group also close to the Ω-loop, which were the highest scoring solutions observed by docking, demonstrated to be very stable during the simulation and more importantly with the appropriate arrangement for the formation of the acyl-enzyme adduct (Figure 5). The results of these MD simulation studies revealed the following: (i) the PDC-1/1–3 complexes were very stable and the inhibitors remained located in the active site throughout the simulation, as revealed by the low RMSD (root-mean-square deviation) values obtained for the enzyme backbone and ligands (Figure S4); (ii) the side chain carrying the catechol group was very flexible and wide variability of arrangements were identified, suggesting that they contribute little to the binding; (iii) the ligands were anchored to the active site by three main hydrogen bonding interactions through the carboxylate group, the carbonyl group of the β-lactam ring, and the ester group in the side chain; (iv) the latter contacts were stronger for ligands 2 and 3, as they appeared to be less mobile in the pocket than 1; (v) the pyridyl moieties in ligands 1–3 were embedded in a tunnel-like site adjacent to the active site, which includes the Lys–Tyr–Lys triad pocket and is isolated from the solvent environment by H10 helix (residues 289–292) (Figure 5A–C); and (vi) the ligands 1–3 induced a close arrangement of the catalytic residues Tyr150 and Lys67, which was not observed in the unbound form.
    The main differences in the binding mode of the inhibitors 1–3 are as follows: (i) ligands 2 and 3 were anchored more strongly than 1. This is readily visualized by comparing several snapshots of the ligands taken throughout the simulation and by analyzing the variation in the distance between the oxygen atom of the catalytic serine and the carbon atom of the β-lactam carbonyl group for the three enzyme complexes (Figure S5) and (ii) the distinct interaction of the corresponding pyridyl moieties with the residues of the tunnel-like site adjacent to the catalytic center, in particular with the catalytic Tyr150 (Figures 5G–I and S6). Thus, for the PDC-1/3 complex, the position of the fluoropyridyl group in 3 was frozen in the pocket by two strong contacts (Figures 5I and S6): (1) an electrostatic interaction between the fluorine substituent and the guanidinium group of Arg148 and (2) a strong π–π stacking interaction between its fluoropyridyl group and the phenol group of Tyr150, which may also cause a reduction in the pKa of Tyr150.(42) Both interactions were very stable throughout the simulation, with average distances of 3.2 and 3.8 Å, respectively. For the PDC-1/2 complex, the interaction between the bromopyridyl moiety in 2 and Tyr150 was less pronounced (average distance of 5.3 Å), and distinct arrangements of this ring were identified (Figures S4 and S6B). The differences in the polarization of the pyridine ring caused by both halogen atoms were due to the variation in their electronegativity [χ(F) = 3.98; χ(Br) = 2.66], which may be explained by their different locations in the ring (meta vs para substitution, respectively). Nonetheless, both ligands 2 and 3 froze the position of Tyr150 in the proximity of Lys93 (Figure S7). By contrast, for the PDC-1/1 complex, a greater conformational freedom of both the pyridyl moiety in 1 and the phenol group of Tyr150, which is located further from Lys67, was observed (Figures 5G and S7).
    Moreover, the studies carried out with the inactivated PDC-1/1–3 enzyme adducts revealed that in all cases, the adducts were anchored by strong polar interactions with residues Ser318 and Arg349 and that their indolizine moieties would be embedded in the deep tunnel-like site surrounded by the inner part of the H10 helix and would establish strong apolar interactions with residues Ala292 and Met291 (Figures 6 and S8). A strong π–π stacking interaction between Tyr150 and the indolizine adducts derived from 2–3, which was absent in 1, was identified and which is promoted by the reduced electron density of these halopyridyl rings. Thus, Tyr150 side chain was stabilized on top of the halogenated rings, and therefore, its position would be frozen in the active site. In addition, comparison of the herein described PDC-1/1–3 enzyme adducts with the X-ray crystal structure of PDC-1 inactivated by avibactam (PDB ID 4OOY,(34) 1.1 Å) revealed that, unlike compounds 1–3, avibactam does not promote interactions with the tunnel-like pocket formed by the H10 helix (Figure 7). The lack of the latter contacts might explain the lower inhibitory capacity of avibactam against PDC-1 relative to inhibitors 1–3.
    Overall, the MD simulation studies carried out on the PDC-1/1–3 enzyme adducts revealed differences in the interactions between the aromatic moieties and the tunnel-like site and the inner part of the H10 helix. Thus, the results suggested that the strong π–π stacking interaction with the catalytic Tyr150, induced by the electron-deficient pyridyl moieties in ligands 2 and 3 or by the corresponding substituted indolizine adducts, would improve their binding. At the same time, this interaction would cause a reduction in the flexibility of Tyr150 that would alter its role in the different stages of the process. We have previously reported a similar freezing effect on the inhibition of the bacterial dehydroquinase enzyme by fluorinated reversible competitive inhibitors.(43) Furthermore, the computational studies herein reported identified the pocket adjacent to the PDC-1 active site and formed by the H10 helix as an important enzyme site for improving or establishing binding of ligand fragments or small molecules. The architecture and nature of this region of the PDC-1 enzyme would be particularly suitable for electron-deficient aromatic rings able to interact with Tyr150, Arg148, and/or apolar residues of H10 helix, among others. Indeed, in a fragment-based discovery approach, Babaoglu and Shoichet(44) also found that 4-methanesulfonylamino benzoic acid and 2-thiophene-2-carboxylic acid bind to the equivalent site of the E. coli AmpC enzyme. This finding was supported by the resolution of the crystal structures of the enzyme in forming a complex with those ligands (PDB IDs 2HDQ and 2HDS), in which a salt bridge with Arg148 and π–π stacking interactions with Tyr150 was identified.
    On the other hand, comparison of the architecture of the tunnel-like pocket identified in the PDC-1 enzyme with that of other AmpC enzymes revealed that this pocket is not fully evident in all cases. Thus, Babaoglu and Shoichet(44) pointed out that in the E. coli AmpC enzyme, the pocket is only fully visible in the presence of the aforementioned aromatic ligands. By contrast, the crystal structure of the extended spectrum and plasmid-encoded AmpC enzyme CMY-10 from Klebsiella aerogenes (PDB ID 5K1D, 1.94 Å),(45) which has a competitive inhibitor, guanosine-5′-monophosphate (GMP), in the active site, but no contact with the inner part of the H10 helix, the equivalent site is a very small narrow cavity. At the same time, in the crystal structure of AmpC BER from E. coli (PDB ID 5GZW, 1.49 Å)(46) in complex with the same inhibitor, GMP, the H10 helix is not solved and the active site appears quite open. Altogether, these findings reinforce the idea that the favorable interactions between the inner part of the H10 helix of the AmpC enzymes and the ligand may induce folding and generation of a pocket that appears to be a suitable target for drug design. This narrow, isolated cavity would enhance ligand binding and protect the enzyme adduct from hydrolysis. To explore this hypothesis, we studied in silico the interaction between compound 2 and the plasmid-encoded AmpC CMY-10 and BER enzymes, in which the architecture observed in the available crystal structures does not indicate a similar pocket for drug design. For the AmpC BER enzyme, the missing residues of the H10 helix were modeled using ModLoop Server,(47,48) and the results were compared with simulations conducted without this helix.
    First, the intrinsic shape-changing motions of CMY-10 and BER enzymes were evaluated by MD simulation studies on their unbound forms and further corroborated by examination of the vibrational modes calculated by principal-component analysis, as implemented in AMBER. The results revealed remarkable differences in the plasticity of the H10 helix, and the size and geometry of the pocket close to the catalytic center are therefore distinct (Figure 8). Thus, in contrast to the CMY-10 enzyme, the H10 helix of the BER enzyme proved very flexible and had a strong capacity to adopt ample and diverse arrangements with a difference of up to ∼9 Å of distance. As a result, in the unbound form, or when no ligand fragments were bound to the Lys–Tyr–Lys triad pocket, this area of the enzyme would be more open, and no tunnel-like/cavity site, as observed in PDC-1 and CMY-10 enzymes, was apparent. However, the simulations performed on the BER/2 binary complex, as well as on the corresponding indolizine adduct, showed that the presence of the aromatic moiety of the ligand would promote folding of the H10 helix and its stabilization over the triad pocket (Figure 9). Accordingly, a deep tunnel-like site such as that observed for the PDC-1 enzyme was identified, while the absence of the H10 helix in the BER/2 binary complex caused destabilization of the ligand and its removal from the catalytic center. These results revealed the high (induced) capacity of the H10 helix to host the ligand. For the CMY-10 enzyme, the conformational changes in the arrangement of H10 helix were small, and the indolizine and pyridyl moieties were deeply buried in the pocket. For both enzymes, strong π–π stacking interactions with the catalytic Tyr150 and apolar contacts with the lipophilic residues of the inner part of the H10 helix [for CMY-10, Ala289, and Ile292 and for BER, Ile291, and Ala292] and the aromatic group in 2 and the resulting indolizine were also identified.
    Overall, these results support the idea that the introduction of electron-deficient aromatic moieties in a scaffold able to reach the not-always-evident tunnel-like site in which the Lys–Tyr–Lys triad is located and isolated from the environment by the H10 helix may be a good approach toward improving the affinity of existing inhibitors of the AmpC enzymes or the development of new inhibitors. The results also suggest that the H10 helix may act as a lid for the Lys–Tyr–Lys triad during catalysis. The protective effect on the indolizine moiety induced by the interaction with the H10 helix in the AmpC enzymes is reminiscent of that caused by the tunnel-like entrance of OXA-24/40 and OXA-23 enzymes.(31) The same type of computational studies carried out with other β-lactamase enzymes, such as TEM-1 from E. coli (class A, PDB ID 1ERM)(49) and OXA-48 from Klebsiella pneumoniae (class D, PDB ID 4S2N)(50) which compounds 1–3 efficiently inactivated, were also performed. However, for the latter enzymes, this type of arrangement, with the indolizine adduct well embedded in the enzyme, was not observed (Figure 10). In these cases, the pyridyl and indolizine moieties would establish numerous lipophilic interactions with apolar residues, as well as CH−π interactions with aromatic residues located in the site adjacent to the active site.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The studies carried out with 6-pyridylmethylene penicillin-based sulfones 1–3 against MDR clinical isolates and laboratory mutant P. aeruginosa strains showing different levels of stable AmpC hyperproduction revealed that these compounds showed similar inhibition efficiency to that of avibactam, decreasing the ceftazidime MICs for all strains tested. Kinetic studies carried out with the PDC-1 enzyme revealed that the introduction of electron-deficient substituents in the pyridyl ring (4-bromopyridyl or 5-fluoropyridyl) is essential for improving the binding affinity for the AmpC of P. aeruginosa. The inhibition proved to be reversible, with a slow deacylation rate, with residence time half-life values between 2.8–3.8-fold higher than those of avibactam. The bromopyridyl derivative 2 proved to be the inhibitor with the highest affinity of the series, as indicated by the approximately fivefold lower KI relative to the parent compound 1 and the highest inhibitory efficiency (kinact/KI), which was respectively 3.3 and 4.2-fold higher than the values yielded by inhibitors 1 and 3. Mass spectrometry (MALDI) studies revealed that these compounds inactivate the PDC-1 enzyme by forming a stable indolizine adduct through the catalytic serine.
    The results of the MD simulation studies carried out on the PDC-1/1–3 binary complexes, which trigger the acylation process, as well as the resulting PDC-1/1–3 adducts, revealed that, in contrast to avibactam, these ligands/adducts would promote additional binding interactions with an adjacent site to the catalytic serine. Thus, the aromatic moieties of these ligands/adducts would be buried in the tunnel-like site formed by the H10 helix, which folded neatly over the Lys–Tyr–Lys triad pocket. Distinct binding interactions (strength and type) of the aromatic moieties in 1–3 with the residues involved in this site were identified. Specifically, the most remarkable contacts identified were π–π stacking interactions with the catalytic Tyr150, lipophilic interactions with the apolar residues of the inner part of H10 helix, and hydrogen bonding interactions with Arg148. The electron-deficiency of the pyridyl rings in 2 and 3, as well as the position of the halogen atom in the ring (meta vs para), which would be absent in 1, are probably responsible for these effects.
    Based on the results of the computational studies carried out on the AmpC enzymes CMY-10, BER, and PDC-1, the attractive interactions promoted by the electron-deficient aromatic ring of the ligands would facilitate generation of this tunnel-like pocket, which is not evident in some of the available crystal structures. These outcomes highlight the potential use of this pocket in AmpC enzymes as a target for the design or optimization of future or existing inhibitors, as well as the high induced-fit capacity of the H10 helix, the architecture of which seems to be readily modulated by the appropriate ligand.
    These outcomes, together with the previously reported excellent results obtained with inhibitors 1–3 against the ESBL CTX-M-2 from Enterobacterales and the class D carbapenemases OXA-23 and OXA-24/40 from A. baumannii,(26) identify these compounds, particularly bromide 2, as broad-spectrum serine-β-lactamase inhibitors capable of restoring the activity of cephalosporins and carbapenems in clinical use against the most important MDR pathogens.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Bacterial Strains and Media

    A collection of P. aeruginosa PAO1 isogenic mutants with different levels of ampC expression were assayed.(33) In addition, PAO1, PAOΔC(18) (PAO1 mutant without an ampC gene), PAOΔC expressing PDC-1 (from PAO1),(51) and PDC-5 (from ATCC 25324, which contained R79Q and T105A substitutions relative to PDC-1)(16) were also assayed.
    A representative isogenic panel of PAO1-derived mutants obtained in previous studies and showing AmpC hyperexpression was included. The collection includes isogenic mutants with single or multiple deletions of the major chromosomal genes involved in the ampC regulatory pathway: the cytosolic amydase ampD and homologues ampDh2 and ampDh3,(52) and the genes coding for the nonessential penicillin-binding proteins PBP4 (dacB), PBP5 (dacC), and PBP7 (pbpG).(33,53) In addition, a panel of six MDR isolates, from the collection of clinical strains obtained in different countries in Europe during from the MagicBullet clinical trial,(54) and two clinical isolates from A Coruña Hospital (Spain) were also included in the study. All strains used are listed in Table 1.
    A VIM-1-producing P. aeruginosa isolate, recovered in a hospital in Majorca (Spain) during a survey to evaluate the incidence of MBL-producing strains, was also included for cloning and purification of the metallo-β-lactamase.(55)
    Bacterial strains were frozen in Luria–Bertani broth (LB) with 10% glycerol and maintained at −80 °C. Strains were grown at 37 °C in LB medium supplemented with gentamicin (30 mg/L) when necessary (Sigma-Genosys).

    Real-Time Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction of the blaampC Gene

    The levels of ampC gene expression were determined by real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT)-PCR, as previously described.(54) Briefly, each strain was grown to an exponential phase (OD600nm = 0.6), and the RNA was isolated using a High Pure RNA Isolation Kit (Roche). RNA samples were treated with DNAse I for 15 min and purified using the RNeasy MinElute Cleanup Kit (QIAGEN). RNA extractions were quantified using a BioDrop lLITE (Isogen Life Science). An aliquot of 50 ng of purified RNA was used in the (RT)-PCR, performed with the LightCycler 480 RNA Master Hydrolysis Probe Kit and in a LightCycler 480 RNA instrument (Roche). The primers 5′-GAAGGCTACGGGGTGAAGA-3′ and 5′-ATGCAGGTTGGCATCGAC-3′ were used to amplify the ampC gene, and the primers 5′-CCGAACTGTGCCTTACCAC-3′ and 5′-GTTCCACCGGCTCGTACA-3′ were used to amplify the rpoB gene (included as a housekeeping gene). Mean values of mRNA levels were determined in three independent replicate assays.

    Compounds 1–3

    They were synthesized in 13 steps from commercially available (+)-6-aminopenicillanic acid, as previously described.(32) The purity of compounds 1–3 was analyzed by NMR and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). HPLC was performed on a Thermo Dionex UltiMate 3000 apparatus equipped with a Brucker amazon SL mass spectrometry detector. Samples were electrophoresed on a Phenomenex kinetex XB-C18 column (particle size = 1.7 μm; dimensions: 50 mm × 2.1 mm, pore size = 100 Å) and eluted at a flow rate of 0.35 mL min–1 with a gradient of 5–75% B in 10 min [A = Milli-Q water + 0.1% TFA; B = acetonitrile + 0.1% TFA]. The purity of all compounds tested was ≥ 95% (Figures S9–S11).

    Purification of β-lactamases

    The enzyme PDC-1 was purified using the GST Gene Fusion System (Amersham). The PDC-1 gene from PAO1 strain (without the region coding for the peptide signal) was amplified and cloned in the pGEX-6P-1 vector with a primer pair containing recognition sites for the restriction enzymes BamHI (5′-AAAGGATCCAAGGAATGGCAAGAAAACAAA-3′) and EcoRI (5′-CCGGAATTCCGGGTCAGCGCTTCA-3′). The recombinant plasmid was electroporated into E. coli BL21, a protease-deficient strain, and selected in LB plates containing 50 mg/L of ampicillin (Sigma-Genosys). This construction generated the fusion protein glutathione S-transferase (GST)/PDC-1. The GST tag was then cleaved off, and the β-lactamase was later purified to homogeneity using affinity chromatography. Finally, after SDS-PAGE, the purified protein appeared as a band of approximately 41 kDa (≥95% purity).
    The metallo-β-lactamase VIM-1 was also purified to homogeneity using the same methodology. The blaVIM-1 gene was amplified from a P. aeruginosa clinical isolate recovered from a hospital in Majorca (Spain) during a survey to evaluate the incidence of MBL-producing strains. The blaVIM-1 gene was cloned in the pGEX-6P-1 vector using the primers V1-F-BHI (5′-TCGGATCCGGGGAGCCGAGTGGTGAG-3′) and V1/13-R-ERI (5′-TCGAATTCCTACTCGGCGACTGAGCG-3′). The fusion protein GST/VIM-1 was later produced, and finally, VIM-1 was purified by affinity chromatography, as previously described.(55)

    Kinetic Experiments

    Inactivation of PDC-1 from P. aeruginosa by compounds 1–3 was evaluated using nitrocefin (Oxoid) as a reporter substrate. All experiments were performed at 25 °C in phosphate-buffered saline pH 7.4 (11.9 mM sodium phosphate dibasic and potassium phosphate monobasic, 137 mM NaCl and 2.7 mM KCl) at λ = 482 nm in an Epoch 2 Microplate spectrophotometer (Biotek). The results shown are the mean values (and standard deviation) of triplicate samples. The value of the Michaelis constant Km for nitrocefin was calculated as previously described.(56)
    The IC50 values were calculated as the inhibitory concentration, resulting in 50% reduction of nitrocefin hydrolysis after 10 min of preincubation of the enzyme and inhibitor at 25 °C, as previously described.(29)
    The apparent Ki (Ki app) was obtained as a competitive inhibition constant in the presence of nitrocefin (≫ Km). Ki app is an equilibrium constant that can be calculated from pre-steady-state conditions, yields an estimated affinity, and represents the formation of the acyl enzyme E-S.(57) Increasing concentrations of each compound were added to the enzyme and nitrocefin mixtures, and the initial velocities (v0) were measured. Inverse initial velocities (1/v0) were plotted against inhibitory concentrations ([I]), and the data were fitted to a linear equation, in which the y intercept divided by the slope of the line was defined as the Ki app observed. The initial velocity (v0) was determined by eq 1. The observed Ki app was then corrected for nitrocefin affinity by using eq 2.(1)(2)
    Inhibitors can be characterized by first-order rate constants for inhibition: (i) kinact, the maximal rate of inactivation achieved with an “infinite” concentration of inactivator, indicates the number of molecules of enzyme that are inactivated per second; thus, the higher the kinact, the faster the rate at which the inhibitor inhibits the enzyme; and (ii) KI value, the concentration of inactivator which yields an inactivation rate that is half the value of kinact. The KI may or may not equal the equilibrium constant Ki, determined under pre-steady-state conditions.(28,56) The kobs values were determined by nonlinear least-squares data fitting, implemented in GraphPad software and using eq 3.(3)where A is the absorbance, v0 is the initial velocity, vf is the final velocity, and x is time. The kobs values were plotted against inhibitory concentrations to determine kinact and KI with eq 4. The KI value was corrected using eq 5.(4)(5)
    The apparent onset of acylation (k2/K) was determined as the slope of the line obtained by plotting [I] against kobs.(29,58)k2/K was determined from eq 6, and this value was corrected for nitrocefin affinity by using eq 7.(6)(7)
    The turnover numbers (tn), defined as the inhibitor/enzyme ratio (I/E) necessary for 90% inhibition of nitrocefin hydrolysis, were determined after 20 h of incubation with increasing concentrations of inhibitors and 10 nM enzymes, with various molar I/E ratios.(29,56)

    Deacylation (koff) Measurement

    Purified PDC-1 at 1 μM was incubated with inhibitors 1–3 at concentrations in excess of the enzyme concentration, for 30 min at 37 °C. The incubation time was long enough to ensure 100% inhibition. The reaction mixture was then diluted 1000-fold in the reaction buffer, and 100 μL of diluted enzyme was mixed with 100 μL of nitrocefin at 200 μM and PDC-1 activity was assayed in a 96-well microtiter plate. Nitrocefin hydrolysis with free enzyme in the absence of the inhibitor was measured as a control. Absorbance at 482 nm was monitored every 20 s for 4 h at 37 °C. The resulting reaction progress curve was fitted to eq 8, which includes the exponential function.(59)(8)where V0 is the initial, completely inhibited enzyme velocity; Vs is the steady-state uninhibited enzyme velocity; and t is time.
    Kinetics assays with these inhibitors were also performed using the metallo-β-lactamase VIM-1, a class B β-lactamase frequently produced by P. aeruginosa.(60) The Ki app parameter was calculated for avibactam and compounds 1–3 against the VIM-1 enzyme.

    Susceptibility Testing of Antibiotics and Inhibitors

    The ceftazidime (Sigma-Genosys) MICs were determined by broth microdilution (gold standard) in the presence and absence of inhibitors 1–3 and avibactam (AstraZeneca) according to EUCAST criteria (Version 9.0).(61) The inhibitors were used at concentrations of 4 and 16 mg/L. Turbidity was recorded in 96-well plates after 20 h of incubation at 37 °C in Mueller–Hinton II broth (Becton-Dickinson). The MICs were determined in three independent replicate assays.

    Mass Spectrometry Studies

    A 100 μL solution of PDC-1 from P. aeruginosa (15 μL from a stock protein concentration of 1.1 mg/mL), in phosphate-buffered saline pH 7.4, was incubated with compounds 1–3 for 30 min. The enzyme/inhibitor molar ratio was 1/100. The activity was monitored by UV–Vis spectroscopy using aliquots from the incubation samples and the control. The enzyme was assayed by monitoring the increase in absorbance at 482 nm in the UV–Vis spectrum due to absorbance of the hydrolyzed nitrocefin (ε/M–1 cm–1 15 900) in phosphate-buffered saline pH 7.4 at 25 °C. Each assay was initiated by addition of nitrocefin. No activity was observed after 30 min, except in the control. For MALDI analysis, the samples were concentrated and successively washed with 5 mM ammonium bicarbonate by centrifugation at 4 °C using Amicon centrifugal filters (Amicon Ultra-10). The samples were freeze-dried, diluted with 5 mM ammonium bicarbonate (5 μL), and analyzed by mass spectrometry in a MALDI TOF/TOF Mass Spectrometer (4800 Analyzer, AbSciex). The ProteoMass MALDI calibration kit (Merck) was used for calibration with sanipic acid as the matrix. Spectra were analyzed using the Data Explorer Software. The experiments were performed in triplicate.

    MD Simulation Studies of the PDC-1 Enzyme in the Unbound Form

    Ligand Preparation

    The ligand geometries were minimized using a restricted Hartree-Fock (RHF) method and a 6-31G(d) basis set, as implemented in the ab initio program Gaussian 09.(62) Partial charges were derived by quantum mechanical calculations by using Gaussian 09, as implemented in the R.E.D. Server (version 3.0),(63−65) according to the RESP(66) model. The covalent modified catalytic serine residue with ligands 1–3 were parameterized using the R.E.D. server, by adding acetyl and N-methyl caps and applying the same procedure used for ligands. RESP charge calculation for the modified serine residue considered the net charge for both acetyl and N-methyl caps to be zero. The missing bonded and nonbonded interaction parameters were assigned, by analogy or through interpolation, from those already present in the AMBER database (GAFF).(67,68)

    Minimization of the Unbound Forms

    The protein coordinates identified in the crystal structure of AmpC from P. aeruginosa PAO1 (PDC-1, PDB ID 4GZB, 1.79 Å)(40) were used. Computation of the protonation state of titratable groups at pH 7.0 was carried out using the H++ Web server.(69,70) As a result of this analysis, His39, His92, His188, His239, His256, and His296 were protonated in the ε position. For the unbound form, the two possible protonation states for Lys67 (neutral and protonated forms) and Tyr150 (neutral and tyrosinate forms) were considered, with both residues either in their neutral or ionic forms. The tyrosinate anion was not included as a parameterized amino acid in the ff14SB(71) force field. Parameterization was carried out using the R.E.D. Server, with the same procedure described above for the modified serine residues. Addition of hydrogen atoms and molecular mechanics parameters from the ff14SB and GAFF force fields, respectively, were assigned to the variant proteins with the LEaP module of AMBER Tools 17. The proteins were immersed in a truncated octahedron of ∼13,500 TIP3P water molecules and neutralized by addition of sodium ions. The system was minimized in three stages: (a) minimization of the solvent and ions (5000 steps, first half with the steepest descent and the other half with the conjugate gradient); (b) minimization of the side chain residues, waters and ions (5000 steps, first half with the steepest descent and the other half with the conjugate gradient); (c) final minimization of the whole system (5000 steps, first half with the steepest descent and the other half with the conjugate gradient). A positional restraint force of 50 kcal mol–1 Å–2 was applied to the whole protein and α carbons during the first two stages (a–b), respectively.

    Simulation of the Unbound Forms

    MD simulations were performed using the pmemd.cuda_SPFP(72−74) module in the AMBER 16 suite of programs. Periodic boundary conditions were applied, and electrostatic interactions were treated using the smooth particle mesh Ewald method,(75) with a grid spacing of 1 Å. The cut-off distance for the unbound interactions was 9 Å. The SHAKE algorithm(76) was applied to all bonds containing hydrogen using a tolerance of 10–5 Å and an integration step of 2.0 fs. The minimized system was then heated at 300 K at 1 atm by increasing the temperature from 0 to 300 K over 100 ps and by maintaining the system at 300 K for another 100 ps. A positional restraint force of 50 kcal mol–1 Å–2 was applied to all α carbons during the heating stage. Finally, the system was equilibrated at constant volume (200 ps with positional restraints of 5 kcal mol–1 Å–2 to α carbons) and constant pressure (another 100 ps with positional restraints of 5 kcal mol–1 Å–2 to α carbons). The positional restraints were gradually reduced from 5 to 1 mol–1 Å–2 (5 steps, 100 ps each), and the resulting systems were allowed to equilibrate (100 ps) without further restraints. Unrestrained MD simulations were carried out for 200 ns. System coordinates were collected every 10 ps for further analysis. The molecular graphics program PyMOL(77) was used for visualization and depiction of enzyme structures. The cpptraj module in AMBER 16 was used to analyze the trajectories and to calculate the rmsd of the protein during the simulation.(78)

    MD Simulation Studies of the PDC-1/1–3 Enzyme Binary Complexes

    Docking Studies

    The neutral protonation states for Lys67 and Tyr150 were used. The binding mode of inhibitors 1–3 was first explored using GOLD software, version 5.8.1,(41) for docking studies and the protein coordinates in PDB 4GZB. For the covalent docking, the enzyme coordinates of the unbound form after 190 ns of simulation were used. All crystallographic water molecules and ligands were removed for docking. The GOLD scoring function was applied. The ligand and the corresponding indolizine adduct geometries, which were previously minimized, were used as MOL2 files. Each ligand was docked in 25 independent genetic algorithm (GA) runs, and for each of these, a maximum of 100,000 GA operations was performed on a single population of 50 individuals. Operator weights for crossover, mutation and migration in the entry box were used as default parameters (95, 95, and 10, respectively) in addition to the hydrogen bonding (4.0 Å) and van der Waals (2.5 Å) parameters. The position of the catalytic serine side chain (Ser64) was used to define the docking region, and the radius was set at 8 Å.

    Minimization of the PDC-1/1–3 Binary Enzyme Complexes and Adducts

    Ligand coordinates obtained by docking were used as a starting point for MD simulations of the corresponding enzyme binary complexes. The complexes immersed in a truncated octahedron of TIP3P water molecules and sodium ions were minimized in four stages: (1) initial minimization of the ligands (1000 steps, first half with the steepest descent and the other half with the conjugate gradient); steps (2), (3), and (4) were performed as steps (a), (b), and (c) for minimization of the unbound forms (see above). A positional restraint force of 50 kcal mol–1 Å–2 was applied to these unminimized atoms during the first three stages (1–3).

    Simulations of the PDC-1/1–3 Binary Enzyme Complexes and Adducts

    MD simulations of the binary complexes were performed as indicated for the unbound protein forms (see above).

    MD Simulation Studies of CMY-10/1–3, BER/1–3, OXA-48/1–3, and TEM-1/1–3 Enzyme Binary Complexes and Adducts

    The protein coordinates identified in the following crystal structures were used: (i) CMY-10 from K. aerogenes (PDB ID 5K1D, 1.94 Å);(45) (ii) BER from E. coli (PDB ID 5GZW, 1.49 Å, chain A);(46) (iii) OXA-48 from K. pneumoniae (PDB ID 4S2N, 2.00 Å, chain A);(50) and (iv) TEM-1 from E. coli (PDB ID 1ERM, 1.70 Å).(49) The studies were carried out as indicated for the PDC-1 enzyme (see above), but with the following specific modifications: (i) for the CMY-10 enzyme, residues His23, His39, His92, His147, His185, His186, His255, His258, and His350 were protonated at the ε position, and His160 was protonated at both δ and ε positions; (ii) for the BER enzyme, the residues His13, His108, His186, His210, His298, and His316 were protonated at the ε position, and the missing residues of H10 helix (287–296) were modeled using the ModLoop Server;(47,48) (iii) for the OXA-48 enzyme, His34, His38, His90, His109, His140, His178, and His182 were protonated at the ε position, and carboxylated Lys73 was prepared in a similar way as the covalently modified serine residue using the R.E.D. Server; and (iv) for the TEM-1 enzyme, His26, His96, His112, His153, His158 and His287 were protonated at the ε position, and Lys73 was considered protonated based on mechanistic considerations. For enzymes OXA-48 and TEM-1, the numbering described in the PDB files was used.
    The vibrational modes for AmpC enzymes (BER, CMY-10, and PDC-1) were calculated by principal component analysis with the cpptraj module from the corresponding MD trajectories.(79)

    Abbreviations
